title: It is a signature looking font use as a logo for "be inspired"
author: raymondeneas

comments.content: Please help me find out what the font that say "Be Inspired" is in this image.

Each of the repeated letters 'i' and 'e' are different. That usually means that it is not a font, but hand-drawn.

This style is similar to a number of popular new script fonts like [Bombshell Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418010735/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/emily-lime/bombshell-pro/?refby=bowfin) from Emily Lime. The foundry has several others with a similar feel. Also Eurotypo, and Trial by Cupcakes (see [Anna Clara](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418010735/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/trial-by-cupcakes/anna-clara/?refby=bowfin)).

- Mike Yanega

Wasn't able to spot a match but I'm clearly not convinced I couldn't be a font. 2 more foundries with fonts in the same vein: [Magpie Paper Works](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418010735/http:/www.myfonts.com/foundry/Magpie_Paper_Works) and [Great Lakes Lettering](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418010735/http:/www.myfonts.com/foundry/Great_Lakes_Lettering). You could also have a look to the [Creative Market Script section](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418010735/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/https%3A/%252Fcreativemarket.com/fonts/script) if you need more alternatives.

One of the versions of Adorn (Garland, perhaps) would do a nice job of approximating the look. Use alternate glyphs for the |b|, |i|, and |d|:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/laura-worthington/adorn/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418010735/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/laura-worthington/adorn/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/laura-worthington/adorn/")
